sign with UAW ON STRIKE printed on it lying on the grass.   " class="css-rq4mmj" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum3-mwlc/27appelbaum3-mwlc-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale" srcset="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum3-mwlc/27appelbaum3-mwlc-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp 600w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum3-mwlc/27appelbaum3-mwlc-jumbo.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp 795w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum3-mwlc/27appelbaum3-mwlc-superJumbo.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp 1590w" sizes="((min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 1004px)) 84vw, (min-width: 1005px) 80vw, 100vw" decoding="async" width="600" height="773" style="cursor: pointer;"></picture></div><figcaption class="css-1ifeaca e1maroi60"><span class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Nick Hagen for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div><div data-testid="placeholder" height="772.828125px" width="600px" class="css-6ggdc6 e11si9ry2"><div data-testid="photoviewer-overlay" class="css-tux0zj e11si9ry3"><div width="200px" height="1210px" data-testid="photoviewer-captionblock" class="css-1kd7c0c e11si9ry1"></div><div width="600px" height="772.828125px" class="css-1fh48tv e11si9ry4"><div style="visibility: hidden; transition: visibility 0s ease 0.5s;"><div class="css-1pq3dr9" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height: auto;"><picture class="css-1j5kxti" style="opacity: 1;"><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 3dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 288dpi)" srcset="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum3-mwlc/27appelbaum3-mwlc-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=600"><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 2dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 192dpi)" srcset="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum3-mwlc/27appelbaum3-mwlc-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=1200"><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 1dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 96dpi)" srcset="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum3-mwlc/27appelbaum3-mwlc-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=1800"><img alt="A picket sign with UAW ON STRIKE printed on it lying on the grass. Media Share buttons, Save button, and Comments Panel with current comment count" class="css-wn12pn"><div class="css-lbtxhr"><ul class="css-1sirvy4"><li class="css-9eyi4s"><div class="css-vxcmzt"><div fill-rule="nonzero"></path></svg></button></div></div></li><li class="css-1xlo06v save-button"><button type="button" role="switch" class="css-1yhvmgx actionbar-button" data-testid="save-article-button" aria-label="Save article for reading later..." aria-checked="false" aria-busy="false" aria-live="polite"><svg width="12" height="18" viewBox="0 0 12 18" class="css-1fag8eu"><g fill-rule="nonzero"><path class="saved-fill" d="M1.157 1.268v14.288l4.96-3.813 4.753 3.843V1.268z"></path><path class="saved-stroke" d="m12 18-5.9-4.756L0 17.98V1.014C0 class="css-1xlo06v commentAdjustClass"><button type="button" class="css-1nii3md actionbar-button" aria-label="768 comments. Click to read and post comments." data-testid="comments-speech-bubble-header" id="comments-speech-bubble-header"><div class="css-1mlnk6q"><svg width="21" height="18" viewBox="0 0 21 18" class="css-2urdiw"><path d="m14.52 17.831-5.715-4.545H2.4a1.468 1.468 0 0 1-1.468-1.469V1.894A1.471 1.471 0 0 1 2.4.405h16.583a1.469 1.469 0 0 1 1.469 1.469v9.923a1.469 1.469 0 0 1-1.47 fill-rule="nonzero"></path></svg><span class="css-1re6eyk">768</span></div></button></li><li class="css-fb7l6r"><button type="button" class="css-11jlzyd" data-testid="getstarted-magic-link">Read in app</button><form method="post" action="https://nytimes.app.goo.gl/?link=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/09/27/opinion/editorials/uaw-strike-workweek-hours.html&amp;apn=com.nytimes.android&amp;amv=9837&amp;ibi=com.nytimes.NYTimes&amp;isi=284862083" data-testid="MagicLinkForm" style="visibility: hidden;"><input name="client_id" type="hidden" value="web.fwk.vi"><input name="redirect_uri" type="hidden" value="https://nytimes.app.goo.gl/?link=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/09/27/opinion/editorials/uaw-strike-workweek-hours.html&amp;apn=com.nytimes.android&amp;amv=9837&amp;ibi=com.nytimes.NYTimes&amp;isi=284862083"><input name="response_type" type="hidden" value="code"><input name="state" type="hidden" value="no-state"><input name="scope" type="hidden" value="default"></form></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="css-103l8m3"><div class="css-t91cuf epjyd6m1"><div class="css-1w5zm64 ey68jwv0" aria-hidden="true"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/binyamin-appelbaum" class="css-uwwqev"><img alt="Binyamin Appelbaum" title="Binyamin Appelbaum" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2019/03/23/opinion/binyamin-appelbaum/binyamin-appelbaum-thumbLarge.png" class="css-owy2rv ey68jwv2"></a></div><div class="css-ehpuw4 epjyd6m0"><p class="css-1tx0lhj e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemprop="name"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/binyamin-appelbaum" class="css-n8ff4n e1jsehar0">Binyamin Appelbaum</a></span></p><div id="enhanced-byline" class="css-8atqhb"><p class="css-1fovwrw e1wtpvyy0">Mr. Appelbaum is a member of the editorial board.</p></div></div></div></div></header><div id="NYT_ABOVE_MAIN_CONTENT_REGION" data-testid="region"><div><div><div><div class=""><div class="css-1lpvp6o"><div class="css-le223v"><div class="css-1ibyhwt"><div class="css-azx95j"><div class="css-13brihr"><span class="css-2ep15g">Sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span class="css-1rhhdjb">Get expert analysis of the news and a guide to the big ideas shaping the world every weekday morning.  <button data-testid="signup-button" class="css-2l0yoh" type="button"><span data-testid="signup-button-span" class="css-u32m0k">Get it sent to your inbox.</span></button></span></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The autoworkers picketing factories across America aren’t just seeking higher pay. They are also, audaciously, demanding the end of the standard 40-hour workweek. They want a full week’s pay for working 32 hours across four days. And we'll all benefit if they succeed.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Americans spend too much time on the job. A shorter workweek would be better for our health, better for our families and better for our employers, who would reap the benefits of a more motivated and better-rested work force. Other countries may seek an advantage in the global marketplace by wringing every drop of labor from their workers; American companies have to be more productive, and that means taking better care of their workers.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In 2015, the city of Gothenburg, Sweden, decided to reduce the workweek for 68 nurses at a city-owned elder-care facility. Instead of eight-hour days, the nurses worked for six hours, and the city hired 15 additional nurses to maintain the same level of staffing. As one might expect, the nurses were happier and healthier. The patients were happier and healthier, too.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">A growing number of similar experiments by companies in other developed countries have yielded similar results. Working less improves the lives of workers — and it also benefits employers. Of the 61 British firms that participated in a six-month <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://static1.squarespace.com/static/60b956cbe7bf6f2efd86b04e/t/63f3df56276b3e6d7870207e/1676926845047/UK-4-Day-Week-Pilot-Results-Report-2023.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">experiment</a> with shorter workweeks last year, 56 decided to let employees continue to work less.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div id="story-ad-1-wrapper" class="css-17u3id6"><div id="story-ad-1-slug" class="css-l9onyx"><p>Advertisement</p></div><a href="#after-story-ad-1" class="css-777zgl">SKIP ADVERTISEMENT</a><div class="ad story-ad-1-wrapper css-rfqw0c" id="story-ad-1" style="" data-google-query-id="CPrsqsLRy4EDFTAX-QAdct8HcA"><div id="google_ads_iframe_/29390238/nyt/opinion/editorials_3__container__" style="border: 0pt none; display: inline-block; width: 728px; height: 90px;"><iframe frameborder="0" src="https://5e68aefc89098f37bb4d1ed86fe8e92e.safeframe.googlesyndication.com/safeframe/1-0-40/html/container.html" id="google_ads_iframe_/29390238/nyt/opinion/editorials_3" title="3rd party ad content" name="" scrolling="no" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" width="728" height="90" data-is-safeframe="true" sandbox="allow-forms allow-popups allow-popups-to-escape-sandbox allow-same-origin allow-scripts allow-top-navigation-by-user-activation" allow="attribution-reporting" role="region" aria-label="Advertisement" tabindex="0" data-google-container-id="2" style="border: 0px; vertical-align: bottom;" data-load-complete="true"></iframe></div></div><div id="after-story-ad-1"></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">While unions have lost much of their power to set standards in the workplace, they can still play a useful role in pioneering changes. The United Auto Workers can establish an example for policymakers to extend to other, nonunion workers through legislation.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Politicians are a cautious bunch when it comes to labor disputes, but President Biden hasn’t hesitated to pick a side in the fight between the United Auto Workers and the “Big Three” automakers. On Tuesday, after <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/09/26/us/politics/biden-uaw-strike-picket-michigan.html" title="">joining</a> General Motors workers on the picket line in Belleville, Mich., he was asked whether they deserved a 40 percent raise. He said yes.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-d754w4 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-1pq3dr9" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height: auto; cursor: pointer;"><picture class="css-1j5kxti" style="opacity: 1;"><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 3dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 288dpi)" srcset="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum2-zvkq/27appelbaum2-zvkq-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=600"><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 2dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 192dpi)" srcset="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum2-zvkq/27appelbaum2-zvkq-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=1200"><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 1dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 96dpi)" srcset="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum2-zvkq/27appelbaum2-zvkq-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=1800"><img alt="President Biden speaking into a megaphone with a group of people standing behind him. " class="css-1m50asq" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum2-zvkq/27appelbaum2-zvkq-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale" srcset="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum2-zvkq/27appelbaum2-zvkq-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp 600w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum2-zvkq/27appelbaum2-zvkq-jumbo.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp 1024w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum2-zvkq/27appelbaum2-zvkq-superJumbo.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp 2048w" sizes="((min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 1004px)) 84vw, (min-width: 1005px) 60vw, 100vw" decoding="async" loading="lazy"></picture></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-gbc9ki ewdxa0s0"><span class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Pete Marovich for The New York Times</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div><div data-testid="placeholder" height="400.1875px" width="600px" class="css-o4wnvw e11si9ry2"><div data-testid="photoviewer-overlay" class="css-tux0zj e11si9ry3"><div width="570px" height="375px" data-testid="photoviewer-captionblock" class="css-13c82i6 e11si9ry1"></div><div width="600px" height="400.1875px" class="css-po2cvv e11si9ry4"><div style="visibility: hidden; transition: visibility 0s ease 0.5s;"><div class="css-1pq3dr9" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height: auto;"><picture class="css-1j5kxti" style="opacity: 1;"><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 3dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 288dpi)" srcset="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum2-zvkq/27appelbaum2-zvkq-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=600"><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 2),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 2dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 192dpi)" srcset="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum2-zvkq/27appelbaum2-zvkq-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=1200"><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 1),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 1dppx),(max-width: 599px) and (min-resolution: 96dpi)" srcset="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum2-zvkq/27appelbaum2-zvkq-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale&amp;width=1800"><img alt="President Biden speaking into a megaphone with a group of people standing behind him. " src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum2-zvkq/27appelbaum2-zvkq-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp&amp;disable=upscale" srcset="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum2-zvkq/27appelbaum2-zvkq-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp 600w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum2-zvkq/27appelbaum2-zvkq-jumbo.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp 1024w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/09/27/multimedia/27appelbaum2-zvkq/27appelbaum2-zvkq-superJumbo.jpg?quality=75&amp;auto=webp 2048w" sizes="((min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 1004px)) 84vw, (min-width: 1005px) 60vw, 100vw" decoding="async" loading="lazy"></picture></div></div></div><button aria-label="Expand this image" data-testid="photoviewer-expand-button" class="css-1vkv6l7 e11si9ry0"><svg width="60" height="60" viewBox="0 0 60 60" fill="none"><circle cx="30" cy="30" r="30" fill="#000" fill-opacity="0.5"></circle><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M23.9665 37.3668L26.5997 40H20V33.4003L22.6332 36.0335L26.6667 32L28 33.3333L23.9665 37.3668Z" fill="#fff"></path><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M36.0335 22.6332L33.4003 20H40V26.5997L37.3668 23.9665L33.3333 28L32 26.6667L36.0335 22.6332Z" fill="#fff"></path></svg></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Mr. Biden ought to be equally vocal in supporting the shift to a 32-hour workweek — and not just for those in the auto industry. He ought to back federal legislation redefining the standard week for all hourly workers. Representative Mark Takano, Democrat of California, introduced a 32-hour <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://takano.house.gov/newsroom/press-releases/congressman-takano-reintroduces-32-hour-workweek-act" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">bill</a> earlier this year. As Mr. Takano has noted, changing the law is particularly important to help blue-collar workers, generally subject to more rigid workplace rules.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Though the 40-hour week may feel like an immutable law of nature, it’s barely a century old.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">American workers fought to establish the eight-hour workday around the turn of the last century, campaigning on the catchy slogan, “Eight hours for work, eight hours for rest, eight hours for what you will.” But the workweek then was six days long for almost everyone.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div id="story-ad-2-wrapper" class="css-1o7t954"><div id="story-ad-2-slug" class="css-l9onyx"><p>Advertisement</p></div><a href="#after-story-ad-2" class="css-777zgl">SKIP ADVERTISEMENT</a><div class="ad story-ad-2-wrapper css-rfqw0c" id="story-ad-2" style="min-height: 250px;"></div><div id="after-story-ad-2"></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In 1922, when Ford became one of the first major employers to commit to a five-day workweek, the announcement <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/1922/03/25/archives/5day-40hour-week-for-ford-employes-new-permanent-working-policy.html" title="">made the front page of this newspaper.</a></p><div></div><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Every man needs more than one day a week for rest and recreation,” said Edsel Ford, the company’s president at the time. “The Ford Company has always sought to promote ideal home life for its employees. We believe that in order to live properly, every man should have more time to spend with his family.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">It took until 1940 for Congress to legislate a 40-hour week. The law said that hourly employees who worked longer got overtime pay.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The union movement back then had an even shorter week high on its list of priorities. In 1933, the Senate passed a bill establishing a 30-hour standard as part of the great rush of legislation at the beginning of President Franklin Roosevelt’s first term. But it went no further, and the 40-hour week soon became conventional.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The revival of the idea partly reflects a shift in societal priorities. Americans have become more protective of their health, more inclined to define themselves in terms of their lives outside work — and perhaps more willing to accept leisure as a substitute for higher pay.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"><div></div></aside></div><div><div id="story-ad-3-wrapper" class="css-1o7t954"><div id="story-ad-3-slug" class="css-l9onyx"><p>Advertisement</p></div><a href="#after-story-ad-3" class="css-777zgl">SKIP ADVERTISEMENT</a><div class="ad story-ad-3-wrapper css-rfqw0c" id="story-ad-3" style="min-height: 250px;"></div><div id="after-story-ad-3"></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Also, there is less work to go around. In a famous 1930 <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.aspeninstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/files/content/upload/Intro_and_Section_I.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">essay</a>, the British economist John Maynard Keynes predicted that by 2030, people would work only 15 hours a week because technological progress would reduce the amount of labor required to meet people’s wants and needs. Keynes greatly underestimated both the will to work and the human capacity to want more stuff. But he wasn’t entirely wrong. The share of Americans who work has been in decline for decades, and while workers still log long hours, the reality of many jobs is better captured by “<a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nbc.com/the-office/about" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">The Office</a>” than, say, <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://americanliterature.com/author/upton-sinclair/book/the-jungle/summary" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">“The Jungle.”</a></p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">People need time for rest and “what you will,” but they still need jobs, too. Work is not just a source of income; it is an essential part of what it means to be human. A shorter workweek would distribute the available opportunities among more people. At the moment, with unemployment low and many employers struggling to find enough workers, that may not seem like an advantage. But as technological progress continues to reduce or eliminate some kinds of work, it makes sense to share what is left.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">It would be fitting for Ford and its workers to once again take the first step into the future.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-798hid etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">The Times is committed to publishing </em><a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/31/opinion/letters/letters-to-editor-new-york-times-women.html" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">a diversity of letters</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> to the editor. We’d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some </em><a class="css-yywogo" href="https://help.nytimes.com/hc/en-us/articles/115014925288-How-to-submit-a-letter-to-the-editor" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">tips</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">. And here’s our email: </em><a class="css-yywogo" href="mailto:letters@nytimes.com" title=""><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">letters@nytimes.com</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p><p class="css-798hid etfikam0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Follow The New York Times Opinion section on </em><a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.facebook.com/nytopinion" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Facebook</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">, </em><a class="css-yywogo" href="http://twitter.com/NYTOpinion" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Twitter (@NYTopinion)</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> and </em><a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.instagram.com/nytopinion/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">Instagram</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div></section><div class="bottom-of-article"><div class="css-ddxw8g"></div><div class="css-1jp38cr"><div class="css-h77nca e1e7j8ap0"><div><p>Binyamin Appelbaum is the lead writer on economics and business for the Times <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/opinion/editorialboard.html">editorial board</a>. He is based in Washington. <span class="css-4w91ra"> <a href="https://twitter.com/BCAppelbaum" class="css-1rj8to8" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank"><span class="css-0">@</span>BCAppelbaum</a> <span class="css-9hqib9">•</span> <a href="https://www.facebook.com/binyamin.appelbaum" class="css-1rj8to8" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Facebook</a> </span></p></div></div></div><div role="toolbar" data-testid="share-tools" aria-label="Social Media Share buttons, Save button, and Comments Panel with current comment count" class="css-wn12pn"><div class="css-10i3hc"><button type="button" class="css-1dg16hf" aria-label="768 comments. Click to read and post comments." data-testid="comments-speech-bubble-bigBottom" id="comments-speech-bubble-bigBottom">Read 768 Comments</button></div><div class="css-jf7ug7"><ul class="css-1sirvy4"><li class="css-9eyi4s"><div class="css-vxcmzt"><div class="css-113xjf1"><button type="button" aria-label="" aria-expanded="false" class="css-1eeh360 actionbar-button" data-testid="gift-article-button"><span class="css-10d8k1f"><svg width="19" height="19" viewBox="0 0 19 19"><path d="M18.04 5.293h-2.725c.286-.34.493-.74.606-1.17a2.875 2.875 0 0 0-.333-2.322A2.906 fill-rule="nonzero"></path></svg>Share full article</span></button></div></div></li><li class="css-1xlo06v"><div class="css-vxcmzt"><div class="css-113xjf1"><button type="button" aria-label="More 0 0 1-.42-.663V11.29c-8.418-.905-10.974 5.177-11.08 5.45a.662.662 0 0 1-.6.453Zm10.048-7.26a16.37 16.37 0 0 1 2.314.158.81.81 0 0 1 .642.726v3.02l6.702-5.682-6.702-5.692v2.883a.767.767 0 0 save-button"><button type="button" role="switch" class="css-1yhvmgx actionbar-button" data-testid="save-article-button" aria-label="Save article for reading later..." aria-checked="false" aria-busy="false" aria-live="polite"><svg width="12" height="18" viewBox="0 0 12 18" class="css-1fag8eu"><g fill-rule="nonzero"><path class="saved-fill" d="M1.157 1.268v14.288l4.96-3.813 4.753 comments. Click to read and post comments." data-testid="comments-speech-bubble-footer" id="comments-speech-bubble-footer"><div class="css-1mlnk6q"><svg width="21" height="18" viewBox="0 0 21 18" class="css-2urdiw"><path d="m14.52 17.831-5.715-4.545H2.4a1.468 1.468 0 0 1-1.468-1.469V1.894A1.471 1.471 0 0 1 2.4.405h16.583a1.469 1.469 0 0 1 1.469 1.469v9.923a1.469 1.469 0 0 1-1.47 1.47H14.58l-.06 4.564ZM2.4 1.645a.228.228 0 0 0-.228.229v9.923a.228.228 0 0 0 .228.229h6.811l4.06 3.235v-3.235h5.652a.228.228 0 0 0 .229-.229V1.874a.228.228 0 0 0-.229-.229H2.4Z" fill="#121212" fill-rule="nonzero"></path></svg><span class="css-1re6eyk">768</span></div></button></li><li class="css-fb7l6r"><button type="button" class="css-11jlzyd" data-testid="getstarted-magic-link">Read in app</button><form method="post" data-testid="MagicLinkForm" style="visibility: hidden;"><input name="client_id" type="hidden" value="web.fwk.vi"><input name="redirect_uri" type="hidden" class="css-l9onyx"><p>Advertisement</p></div><a href="#after-bottom" class="css-777zgl">SKIP ADVERTISEMENT</a><div class="ad bottom-wrapper css-rfqw0c" id="bottom" style="min-height:90px"></div><div id="after-bottom"></div></div></div><div class="css-11kjks6" role="region" aria-label="comments panel" data-testid="comments-panel" tabindex="-1"><button type="button" class="css-159bbcu" aria-label="close comments panel" data-testid="close-comments-panel"><svg class="" viewBox="0 0 12 12" stroke="#666" stroke-width="1" stroke-linecap="round" style="opacity: 0.95;"><line x1="11" y1="1" x2="1" y2="11"></line><line x1="1" y1="1" x2="11" y2="11"></line></svg></button><div class="css-1h21wu5"><div class="css-akb3vb"><div><div class="css-1yip8nf"><header><h2 class="css-1sj8ssj"><a href="#commentsContainer" tabindex="-1" aria-label="Comments Panel">Comments <span>768</span></a></h2><a class="css-emn6zw" href="">The Magic Number: 32 Hours a Week</a><a href="" class="css-1qg0wjs" tabindex="0">Skip to Comments</a></header><div class="css-1q7njkh"><a href="https://myaccount.nytimes.com/auth/login?response_type=cookie&amp;client_id=vi&amp;redirect_uri=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2023%2F09%2F27%2Fopinion%2Feditorials%2Fuaw-strike-workweek-hours.html"><span class="css-1gp0kkr">Share your thoughts.</span></a><div class="css-1tgtjhp">The Times needs your voice. We welcome your on-topic commentary, criticism and expertise. <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/content/help/site/usercontent/usercontent.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">Comments are moderated for civility.</a></div></div></div><div class="css-1bxnhxc"></div><div class="css-1yip8nf"></div></div></div></div></div></article></div></main><nav class="css-1jmk4jh" id="site-index" aria-labelledby="site-index-label" data-testid="site-index"><h2 class="css-1dv1kvn" id="site-index-label">Site Index</h2><div class="css-uc4bdz"></div></nav><footer class="css-1e1s8k7 dockVisible" role="contentinfo"><nav data-testid="footer" class="css-1qa4qp6"><h2 class="css-1dv1kvn">Site Information Navigation</h2><ul class="css-1ho5u4o edvi3so0"><li data-testid="copyright"><a class="css-t8x4fj edvi3so1"><li class="css-a7htku edvi3so2"><a data-testid="footer-link" class="css-jq1cx6" href="https://www.nytco.com/">NYTCo</a></li><li class="css-a7htku edvi3so2"><a data-testid="footer-link" class="css-jq1cx6" href="https://help.nytimes.com/hc/en-us/articles/115015385887-Contact-Us">Contact Us</a></li><li class="css-a7htku edvi3so2"><a data-testid="footer-link" href="https://www.nytco.com/careers/">Work with us</a></li><li class="css-a7htku edvi3so2"><a data-testid="footer-link" class="css-jq1cx6" href="https://nytmediakit.com/">Advertise</a></li><li href="https://www.nytimes.com/privacy/privacy-policy">Privacy Policy</a></li><li class="css-a7htku edvi3so2"><a data-testid="footer-link" class="css-jq1cx6" href="https://help.nytimes.com/hc/en-us/articles/115014893428-Terms-of-service">Terms of Service</a></li><li class="css-a7htku edvi3so2"><a data-testid="footer-link" class="css-jq1cx6" They are also, audaciously, demanding the end of the standard 40-hour workweek. They want a full week’s pay for working 32 hours across four days. And we'll all benefit if they succeed.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":0,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Americans spend too much time on the job. A shorter workweek would be better for our health, better for our families and better for our employers, who would reap the benefits of a more motivated and better-rested work force. Other countries may seek an advantage in the global marketplace by wringing every drop of labor from their workers; American companies have to be more productive, and that means taking better care of their workers.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":1,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"In 2015, the city of Gothenburg, Sweden, decided to reduce the workweek for 68 nurses at a city-owned elder-care facility. Instead of eight-hour days, the nurses worked for six hours, and the city hired 15 additional nurses to maintain the same level of staffing. As one might expect, the nurses were happier and healthier. The patients were happier and healthier, too.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":2,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"A growing number of similar experiments by companies in other developed countries have yielded similar results. Working less improves the lives of workers — and it also benefits employers. Of the 61 British firms that participated in a six-month ","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"experiment","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fstatic1.squarespace.com\u002Fstatic\u002F60b956cbe7bf6f2efd86b04e\u002Ft\u002F63f3df56276b3e6d7870207e\u002F1676926845047\u002FUK-4-Day-Week-Pilot-Results-Report-2023.pdf","title":"","uri":null}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":" with shorter workweeks last year, 56 decided to let employees continue to work less.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsDesktop":true,"index":3,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"While unions have lost much of their power to set standards in the workplace, they can still play a useful role in pioneering changes. As Mr. Takano has noted, changing the law is particularly important to help blue-collar workers, generally subject to more rigid workplace rules.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsDesktop":false,"index":7,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Though the 40-hour week may feel like an immutable law of nature, it’s barely a century old.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"American workers fought to establish the eight-hour workday around the turn of the last century, campaigning on the catchy slogan, “Eight hours for work, eight hours for rest, eight hours for what you will.” But the workweek then was six days long for almost everyone.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":true,"index":8,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"In 1922, when Ford became one of the first major employers to commit to a five-day workweek, the announcement ","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"made the front page of this newspaper.","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F1922\u002F03\u002F25\u002Farchives\u002F5day-40hour-week-for-ford-employes-new-permanent-working-policy.html","title":"","uri":null}]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":9,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“Every man needs more than one day a week for rest and recreation,” said Edsel Ford, the company’s president at the time. “The Ford Company has always sought to promote ideal home life for its employees. We believe that in order to live properly, every man should have more time to spend with his family.”","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":10,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"It took until 1940 for Congress to legislate a 40-hour week. The law said that hourly employees who worked longer got overtime pay.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":true,"adsDesktop":false,"index":11,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The union movement back then had an even shorter week high on its list of priorities. In 1933, the Senate passed a bill establishing a 30-hour standard as part of the great rush of legislation at the beginning of President Franklin Roosevelt’s first term. But it went no further, and the 40-hour week soon became conventional.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":12,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The revival of the idea partly reflects a shift in societal priorities. Americans have become more protective of their health, more inclined to define themselves in terms of their lives outside work — and perhaps more willing to accept leisure as a substitute for higher pay.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":13,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Also, there is less work to go around. In a famous 1930 ","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"essay","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.aspeninstitute.org\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002Ffiles\u002Fcontent\u002Fupload\u002FIntro_and_Section_I.pdf","title":"","uri":null}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":", the British economist John Maynard Keynes predicted that by 2030, people would work only 15 hours a week because technological progress would reduce the amount of labor required to meet people’s wants and needs. Keynes greatly underestimated both the will to work and the human capacity to want more stuff. But he wasn’t entirely wrong. The share of Americans who work has been in decline for decades, and while workers still log long hours, the reality of many jobs is better captured by “","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The Office","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nbc.com\u002Fthe-office\u002Fabout","title":"","uri":null}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"” than, say, ","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“The Jungle.”","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Famericanliterature.com\u002Fauthor\u002Fupton-sinclair\u002Fbook\u002Fthe-jungle\u002Fsummary","title":"","uri":null}]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":14,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"People need time for rest and “what you will,” but they still need jobs, too. Work is not just a source of income; it is an essential part of what it means to be human. A shorter workweek would distribute the available opportunities among more people. At the moment, with unemployment low and many employers struggling to find enough workers, that may not seem like an advantage. But as technological progress continues to reduce or eliminate some kinds of work, it makes sense to share what is left.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":15,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"It would be fitting for Ford and its workers to once again take the first step into the future.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"RelatedLinksBlock","displayStyle":"STANDARD","title":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"More on the autoworkers’     <script>
    (function(){
      if (document.cookie.indexOf('NYT-S') === -1) {
        var iframe = document.createElement('iframe');
        iframe.height = 0;
        iframe.width = 0;
        iframe.style.display = 'none';
        iframe.style.visibility = 'hidden';
        iframe.src = 'https://myaccount.nytimes.com/auth/prefetch-assets';
        document.body.appendChild(iframe);
      }
    })();

<script type="text/javascript" id="">!function(d){function x(){var f,a;if(a=d.crypto||d.msCrypto)a=a.getRandomValues(new Uint8Array(18));else for(a=[];18>a.length;)a.push(256*Math.random()^255&(f=f||+new Date)),f=Math.floor(f/256);return btoa(String.fromCharCode.apply(String,a)).replace(/\+/g,"-").replace(/\//g,"_")}var r,t,p,B,l,q,u=[],m={pv_id:"",ctx_id:"",intra:!1,force_xhr:!1,store_last_response:!1},C="object"==typeof d.navigator&&"string"==typeof d.navigator.userAgent&&/iP(ad|hone|od)/.test(d.navigator.userAgent),y="object"==typeof d.navigator&&

!t)){if(t=m.ctx_id||x(),"string"!=typeof c[1]||!/^http/.test(c[1]))throw Error("init must include an et host url");if(r=String(c[1]).replace(/([^\/])$/,"$1/"),"string"!=typeof c[2])throw Error("init must include a source app name");B=c[2]}var h=c.length-1;(a=c[h]&&"object"==typeof c[h]?c[h]:a)||/init/.test(c[0])?a&&!a.subject&&console.warn("event data {} must include a subject"):console.warn("when invoked without 'init' or 'pageinit', nyt_et() must include a event data");r&&a&&a.subject&&(h=a.subject,

<script type="text/javascript" id="">nyt_et.get_pageview_id()||nyt_et("init",google_tag_manager["rm"]["2703797"](14),google_tag_manager["rm"]["2703797"](16),{subject:"page",canonicalUrl:(document.querySelector("link[rel\x3dcanonical]")||{}).href,articleId:(document.querySelector("meta[name\x3darticleid]")||{}).content,pubpEventId:(document.querySelector("meta[name\x3dpubp_event_id]")||{}).content,nyt_uri:(document.querySelector("meta[name\x3dnyt_uri]")||{}).content,url:location.href,referrer:"",client_tz_offset:(new Date).getTimezoneOffset(),gtm:google_tag_manager["rm"]["2703797"](21),
